description: Borrowed from Latin integrātus, perfect participle of integrō (“I make whole, I renew, I repair, I begin again”), from integer (“whole, fresh”); see integer, integral.

verbs.description: integrate (third-person singular simple present integrates, present participle integrating, simple past and past participle integrated)

entries.meaning: To form into one whole; to make entire; to complete; to renew; to restore; to perfect.
To include as a constituent part or functionality.
examples: They were keen to integrate their new skills into the performance.

entries.meaning: To indicate the whole of; to give the sum or total of; as, an integrating anemometer, one that indicates or registers the entire action of the wind in a given time.
(mathematics) To subject to the operation of integration; to find the integral of an equation.
To desegregate, as a school or neighborhood.
examples: The refugees were well integrated into the community.

entries.meaning: (genetics) To combine compatible elements in order to incorporate them.
